page-1.text: Animation using a 128 bit size for each the data block and the key

page-3.title: Input
page-3.explanation-left: This is a block from the plaintext message to be encrypted

page-4.title: Encryption Process
page-4.text: (Performing the encryption of the given plaintext block using 4 diffrent transformation in the initial round, the 9 main rounds and the final round)

page-9.title: 3 - MixColumns
page-9.text: The four numbers of one column are modulo multiplied in Rijndael's Galois Field by a given matrix.
page-9.text2: The MixColumns step along wit hthe ShiftRows step is the primary source of diffusion in Rijndael.

page-10.title: 4 - AddRoundKey
page-10.roundKeyText: (Produced as Round key 1 during the Key Schedule - see slide 14

page-11.intoText: These transformations are applied to the State for 9 more rounds. The final round does not include the MixColumns transformation.

page-12.intoText: These transformations are applied to the State for 9 more rounds. The final round does not include the MixColumns transformation.

page-13.title: Key Schedule
page-13.text: (Expansion of the given Cipher key into 11 partial keys, used in the initial round, the 9 main rounds and the final round)

page-14.title: Key Schedule
page-14.textIntro: The expanded key can be seen as an array of 32-bit words (columns), numbered from 0 to 43. The first four columns are filled with the given Cipher key
page-14.text: Words in positions that are multiple of 4 (W4, W5, ..., W40) are calculated by:
page-14.textA: a) applying the RotWord and SubBytes transformation to the previous word wi-1
page-14.textB: b) Adding (XOR) this result to the word 4 positions earlier wi-4, plus a round constatn Rcon
page-14.textXOR: The remaining 32-bit words wi, are calculated by adding (XOR) the previous word wi-1 with the word 4 positions earlier Wi-4
